Catapult Class for Consistent Printing

catapult.Rd

Creates an object of class "catapult" with a built-in title string used for printing.

Usage

catapult(object = vector(), lead = "Catapult", revert = FALSE, ...)

# S3 method for class 'catapult'
print(x, ...)

Arguments

object

Object to be converted to "catapult" class.

lead

a character string giving the title to be printed.

revert

logical indicating whether the "revert" attribute should be set to TRUE or FALSE. By default, when FALSE, the corresponding print method print.catapult() will invoke further print methods for the underlying inherited object; if TRUE, print.catapult() will return to the calling function after printing lead.

...

additional named arguments to be forwarded to print methods of classes inherited from object, for example as required for formatting and printing a data frame.

x

an object used to select a method.

Value

An object of class "catapult" inheriting class(es) from object.

Details

catapult() converts an object to class "catapult", inheriting from its existing class(es).

Note

Deprecated, use instead ParaAnita announce().

See also

cat(), print().

Other print: lf(), print_all()

Examples

catapult()
#> ___________
#> Catapult: -
#> 
#> logical(0)
(cpt <- catapult("x", lead = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet"))
#> _____________________________
#> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet: -
#> 
#> [1] "x"
.class2(cpt)
#> [1] "catapult"  "character"
attr(cpt, "revert")
#> [1] FALSE

(cpt <- catapult("x", lead = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet", TRUE))
#> _____________________________
#> Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet: -
#> 
.class2(cpt)
#> [1] "catapult"  "character"
attr(cpt, "revert")
#> [1] TRUE

rm(cpt)
